message:
ف حاجة عايز اعرف انا فاهمه صح ولا غلط , و جزاكم الله خيرا 
و هي الفرق بين  value and reference types
هو اناا اليل فاهمه ان ف حالة ال Value فلنفترض اننا عندنا variable و ليكن x و اسندنا اليه قيمة و لتكن 5 ثم اسندنا ال x للمتغير y
معني ذلك ان y  هياخد كوبي من القيمة المخزنة ف ال x
اما في حالة ال reference 
فلمفترض اننا عندنا Class اسمه Student و جواه id , name 
و بعد كده ف ال main خدنا object من الكلاس student , و ليكن st1و اسندنا اليه القيم 
ثم اخدنا اوبجكت من Student و ليكن st2 و اسندنا اليه الآوبجكت st1 
lمعني ذلك ان دلوقتي st2 , st1 بيشاورا ع ال address لنفس القيم الآصلية بمعني 
ان اي تغيير في القيم لاي من ال 2 اوبجكت هياثر و يظهر ع التاني

data.message: Yes consider them as two remote-controls control the same T.V

MohAmed HAmada now you have extra step to clarify .. why we need to use the keyword 'ref' in certain cases?
---
it is clear for you or it need some clarification?

I know the reason of using keyword 'ref' with an argument to control the value for example if we have a value as an argument  and doing on it some calculation it will be effect on the value itself on the Main 
Ahmed Mozaly

this is right for value types,
one other thing, we can use 'ref' keyword for reference types too, why the need?
---
for example
public void Send(ref UserMessage userMessage){
.....
}
it is all about the 'new' keyword
and in NotificationHelper.Send(x); NO new envelops will be created in case of using 'ref' keyword, instead the same envelop will be passed to the method

thanks i understand it from MSDN so i deleted my comment but what i understood that it  changes the address that is stored in   
        parameter . Because parameter is a ref parameter, the 
      address that is stored in variable item in Main also is changed !!
i think it work as the value type change the origin value in Main by changing the address of it

The way I think about using ref with a reference type, is that it sends a reference to the reference (a pointer of a pointer in C++ terms), same thing with "out" except that the compiler will warn you if you send an uninitialized variable to a ref parameter (while it wont if it's an out parameter), which makes a lot of sense.
